Posts.Content: May 20, 2012 07:31AM stickwitch28 wrote: Thanks ali68. I was told almost all of it. My surgeon isn't taking any chances. I can't get a lumpectomy because my tumor is considered large for my breast size and near the nipple, so it was really out for me. I even came to research about cryosurgery in the US and in China but still out. So its just mastectomy for me. I didnt want to take the FISH test but I was told it was really needed for me to get a comprehensive treatment. Good luck on your surgery on the 15th, I will be praying for you.

Posts.Title: May 2012 Mastectomies? Still_Snarky Fearlessfoot

Posts.Content: Jun 16, 2012 10:27AM stickwitch28 wrote: I had my right MX last month.I was quite happy with my C cups since they arrived when I was in high school, better than flat-chested classmates and not to big for the guys to forget to look at my face when they introduce themselves (unlike another friend of mine). I was 100 % happy. After college came and surfing became my favorite sport, I used to get my top always losing its battle with the combined powers of pounding waves and sunblock that I was beginning to think, 'ok, happy with my boobs 95% of the time.' When I had my diagnosis, I cried for weeks that I was going to lose my right boobs, the side my cat loves to use as a pillow when he needs a warmer one than his own and no more v-neck tops and baby doll dresses and tiny bikinis. But hey, losing one boob is better than losing a life, bluntly said by someone I know who doesn't really know what I am going through. My kind sister and her friend was so great to skip a day at the office to give me a photoshoot at a nearby island 2 days before my MX. They say for posterities sake....Here is the page of my pictures: thresca.tumblr.com/page/2. I remember when they wheeled me in surgery that all the nurses where males and only females were the anesthesiologist and the surgeon. No worries. We were three scheduled for MX that day. My surgeon told me when the next day that the team was shocked because my boobs were 'beautiful and perfect'....well, on the outside.... After the surgery, I realized I can now wear bandeau tops instead of teeny bikinis....my cat has now moved to the left boob since I had to spank his claws and paws sinking on my tender surgical scars on the right. I am now enjoying bouson tops and knitted dresses that dont hint if I am uniboob or boob+foob....Life goes on...
Posts.Title: Mourning my breasts pre-mastectomy...A eulogy NanG crystalphm

Posts.Content: May 15, 2012 09:38PM stickwitch28 wrote: I got a formal diagnosis last May 2. I was looking for options such as cryosurgery, even in China where they have this wonderful cancer hospital named Fuda Cancer Hospital. Well, it so happened mine has to be a mastectomy. I am presently waiting for the doctor's call when it will be, either this weekend or early next week. Praying for everybody out there who will be having their bmx.

Posts.Content: May 19, 2012 12:58PM stickwitch28 wrote: Hi Ellebee. Trust your gut, that's true. You are now doing your homework. That's great:) Read as much as you can and list the questions you would want to ask your doctor. GraciousGal has outlined some of possible diagnostic and procedures you may undergo. If you are not comfortable with the surgeon,go to another. Check their experience and their credentials, too. The surgeon should be able to answer all your questions and provide you with additional information you may need in order to make a sound decision and put you at ease with the procedure. They usually know plastics surgeo whom they have worked with and may recommend you for further consult should you go for reconstruction. Goodluck and take care:)
